title: Ivan Perišić
text:
Ivan Perišić (; born 2 February 1989) is a Croatian professional <a href="Association%20football">footballer</a> who plays for <a href="Serie%20A">Serie A</a> club <a href="Inter%20Milan">Inter Milan</a> and the <a href="Croatia%20national%20football%20team">Croatia national team</a>. Usually deployed as a <a href="Midfielder%23Winger">winger</a>, he also featured as an <a href="Midfielder%23Attacking%20midfielder">attacking midfielder</a> or <a href="Forward%20%28association%20football%29%23Second%20striker">second striker</a>.
A product of the <a href="HNK%20Hajduk%20Split">Hajduk Split</a> and <a href="FC%20Sochaux-Montb%C3%A9liard">Sochaux</a> youth academies, Perišić made a name for himself while playing for <a href="Club%20Brugge%20KV">Club Brugge</a>, where he was the <a href="Belgian%20First%20Division%20A%20top%20scorers">Belgian Pro League top goalscorer</a> and was named <a href="Belgian%20professional%20football%20awards%23Professional%20Footballer%20of%20the%20Year">Belgian Footballer of the Year</a> for 2011. This earned him a transfer to <a href="Borussia%20Dortmund">Borussia Dortmund</a>, with whom he won the <a href="2011%E2%80%9312%20Bundesliga">2011–12 Bundesliga</a>, before signing with <a href="VfL%20Wolfsburg">VfL Wolfsburg</a> for €8 million in January 2013. He remained there for two and a half seasons, winning the <a href="2015%20DFB-Pokal%20Final">2015 DFB-Pokal Final</a>, before moving to <a href="Inter%20Milan">Inter Milan</a> for €16 million. In 2019, he joined <a href="FC%20Bayern%20Munich">Bayern Munich</a> on loan, winning the <a href="Treble%20%28association%20football%29">treble</a>. After returning to Inter Milan, he won the <a href="2020-21%20Serie%20A">2020-21 Serie A</a> and the <a href="2021%20Supercoppa%20Italiana">2021 Supercoppa Italiana</a>.
Perišić made his debut for the Croatia national team in 2011, and represented his nation at <a href="UEFA%20Euro%202012">Euro 2012</a>, <a href="UEFA%20Euro%202016">2016</a> and <a href="UEFA%20Euro%202020">2020</a>, as well as the <a href="2014%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">2014</a> and <a href="2018%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">2018 World Cup</a>, reaching the <a href="2018%20FIFA%20World%20Cup%20Final">final</a> of the latter. Instrumental to <a href="Croatia%20national%20football%20team%23Dali%C4%87%20period%20and%20the%20second%20%26quot%3Bgolden%20generation%26quot%3B%20%282017%E2%80%93present%29">Croatia's second "golden generation"</a>, Perišić is the nation's player with most goal contributions at the major tournaments (14), and the first Croatian player ever to score in a World Cup final.
Club career.
Early career.
Perišić played in the youth ranks of the club he grew up supporting, <a href="HNK%20Hajduk%20Split">Hajduk Split</a>. He received interest from a number of clubs, including <a href="R.S.C.%20Anderlecht">Anderlecht</a>, <a href="PSV%20Eindhoven">PSV</a>, <a href="AFC%20Ajax">Ajax</a>, <a href="Hertha%20BSC">Hertha BSC</a> and <a href="Hamburger%20SV">Hamburger SV</a>. The only match he played for Hajduk was a friendly 3–1 win over <a href="FK%20Smederevo%201924">Smederevo</a> in <a href="Murska%20Sobota">Murska Sobota</a> on 16 July 2006. Returning from Murska Sobota to <a href="Split%2C%20Croatia">Split</a>, Perišić received offers from Anderlecht and <a href="FC%20Sochaux-Montb%C3%A9liard">Sochaux</a>. Hajduk offered Perišić a €100,000 contract, which was only €20,000 less than Hajduk's best player <a href="Niko%20Kranj%C4%8Dar">Niko Kranjčar</a>'s contract. However, the Perišić family opted for French club Sochaux, which paid €360,000 to sign him in the summer of 2006. Sochaux's coach <a href="Alain%20Perrin">Alain Perrin</a> personally arrived to Split with a private jet to convince Perišić to sign, waiting two days for his signature. His physical and technical attributes led to comparisons to former Croatia international <a href="Aljo%C5%A1a%20Asanovi%C4%87">Aljoša Asanović</a> by some journalists. He was a member of the Sochaux youth team, which won the <a href="Coupe%20Gambardella">Coupe Gambardella</a> in 2007. During his time at Sochaux, he failed to make a first-team appearance, but did play for the B team. In January 2009, Perišić was sent on loan to <a href="Belgian%20First%20Division%20A">Belgian top flight</a> club <a href="K.S.V.%20Roeselare">Roeselare</a> for six months. At the end of the <a href="2008%E2%80%9309%20Belgian%20First%20Division">2008–09 season</a>, there were reports Perišić sought to join Belgian side Anderlecht.
Club Brugge.
On 26 August 2009, Belgian club <a href="Club%20Brugge%20KV">Club Brugge</a> acquired Perišić from Sochaux for a €250,000 transfer fee and signed him to a three-year contract. Prior his move, Perišić was linked with a move to German side Hertha BSC, having gone on trial.
In the opening match of the season, Perišić scored his first goal in a 1–1 draw against <a href="K.R.C.%20Genk">Genk</a>, then scored his second in two consecutive games and provided assists in a 4–1 win over <a href="K.V.C.%20Westerlo">Westerlo</a>. Overall, Perišić scored 9 goals in 33 league appearances, also making eight appearances in Brugge's <a href="2009%E2%80%9310%20UEFA%20Europa%20League">Europa League</a> campaign, scoring four goals. At the end of the season, Perišić signed a new three-year contract at Brugge, keeping him until 2015.
Belgian football critics predicted a bright future for Perišić. In the <a href="2010%E2%80%9311%20Belgian%20Pro%20League">2010–11 season</a>, he was the top scorer of the Belgian Jupiler Pro League after scoring 22 goals for Club Brugge, also being named <a href="Belgian%20professional%20football%20awards%23Professional%20Footballer%20of%20the%20Year">Player of the Year</a> in Belgium. During the season, Perišić scored four goals and provided an assist in a 5–0 win against <a href="R.%20Charleroi%20S.C.">Charleroi</a> on 29 December 2010.
Borussia Dortmund.
On 23 May 2011, Perišić signed a five-year contract to play for German side <a href="Borussia%20Dortmund">Borussia Dortmund</a> after Dortmund paid an estimated €5 million transfer fee to Brugge. He made his debut for the club in their 3–1 home victory over Hamburger SV on 5 August, substituting on for <a href="Chris%20L%C3%B6we">Chris Löwe</a> in the 75th minute. During a <a href="2011%E2%80%9312%20UEFA%20Champions%20League">Champions League</a> match on 13 September 2011, he scored a late equaliser with a volley from 20 yards against <a href="Arsenal%20F.C.">Arsenal</a> after entering as a substitute in the 69th minute. On 14 October, he scored the first goal in a 2–0 win against <a href="SV%20Werder%20Bremen">Werder Bremen</a>, a match in which he was later sent off for a second bookable offence. On 21 April 2012, he scored the important 1–0 goal against <a href="Borussia%20M%C3%B6nchengladbach">Borussia Mönchengladbach</a> and opened the door to the eighth national championship for Dortmund. The game ended 2–0 (the second was scored by <a href="Shinji%20Kagawa">Shinji Kagawa</a>).
Perišić began the <a href="2012%E2%80%9313%20Bundesliga">2012–13 Bundesliga</a> season scoring a brace in a 3–2 loss against Hamburger SV on 22 September 2012. However, Perišić soon found his first team opportunities limited, having played less in the first team and soon told Croatian channel <a href="Nova%20TV%20%28Croatia%29">Nova TV</a> he had received no support from Dortmund manager <a href="J%C3%BCrgen%20Klopp">Jürgen Klopp</a> and accused him of favouring other players. In response, Klopp criticised his actions as childish and Perišić faced a fine due to his comment.
VfL Wolfsburg.
On 6 January 2013, it was reported Perišić transferred for €8 million to <a href="VfL%20Wolfsburg">VfL Wolfsburg</a>. He scored his first goal for Wolfsburg in a friendly match against <a href="Standard%20Li%C3%A8ge">Standard Liège</a> on 10 January. He made his competitive debut for Wolfsburg against <a href="VfB%20Stuttgart">VfB Stuttgart</a> on 19 January 2013. In March, he suffered a left knee injury that sidelined him throughout March and April. He made his comeback in May in the match against Hamburger SV, coming on as a substitute and providing an assist. On 11 May 2013, he faced his former club Borussia Dortmund, scoring two goals.
On 3 August 2013, Perišić scored his first cup goal for Wolfsburg in their 3–1 win against <a href="Karlsruher%20SC">Karlsruher SC</a>. On 26 October 2013, Perišić opened his goal scoring form in the <a href="2013%E2%80%9314%20Bundesliga">2013–14 season</a> in their 3–0 win against Werder Bremen, also creating an assist on a goal. On matchday 30, he scored a brace in Wolfsburg's 4–1 home win against <a href="1.%20FC%20N%C3%BCrnberg">1. FC Nürnberg</a>. Perišić finished the season with ten league goals, second-best on the team behind fellow countryman <a href="Ivica%20Oli%C4%87">Ivica Olić</a>.
Inter Milan.
On 30 August 2015, Perišić signed with Italian club <a href="Inter%20Milan">Inter Milan</a> on a five-year contract for a transfer fee of €16 million. He was presented on 10 September alongside <a href="Adem%20Ljaji%C4%87">Adem Ljajić</a>, where he was assigned squad number 44, stating, "Inter were too big an opportunity to turn down."
2015–16 season.
Perišić made his competitive debut for the club three days later, starting and playing 85 minutes in a 1–0 win against cross-city rivals <a href="A.C.%20Milan">Milan</a> in the "<a href="Derby%20della%20Madonnina">Derby della Madonnina</a>". He opened his scoring account on 4 October in his fifth league appearance in the 1–1 away draw against <a href="U.C.%20Sampdoria">Sampdoria</a>, profiting from <a href="Mauro%20Icardi">Mauro Icardi</a>'s assist, which was followed by another goal against <a href="U.S.%20Citt%C3%A0%20di%20Palermo">Palermo</a> two weeks later.
On 15 December, Perišić made his <a href="2015%E2%80%9316%20Coppa%20Italia">Coppa Italia</a> debut in the round of 16 match against <a href="Cagliari%20Calcio">Cagliari</a> at home, appearing as a second-half substitute and scoring the team's third goal of the match in an eventual 3–0 win. He began 2016 on 6 January in the match away against <a href="Empoli%20F.C.">Empoli</a>; his cross from close range was finished home by Icardi for the only goal of the match, which kept Inter top to the table. On 7 February, during the match against <a href="Hellas%20Verona%20F.C.">Hellas Verona</a>, Perišić came on as a 46th-minute substitute to change the fate of the match, providing an assist for Icardi and also scoring for himself to level the result 3–3, rescuing a point for his side.
March was Perišić's best month in personal terms, scoring four goals and providing three assists. On 2 March, in the returning leg of Coppa Italia's semi-final against <a href="Juventus%20F.C.">Juventus</a> at <a href="San%20Siro">San Siro</a>, Perišić scored the team's second goal of the match to help Inter overturn the 3–0 defeat and equal the aggregate 3–3, which led the match into the penalty shoot-outs. However, Inter lost 5–3 and were eliminated from the competition. Perišić scored Inter's last goal of <a href="2015%E2%80%9316%20Inter%20Milan%20season">2015–16 season</a> in a 2–1 home win against Empoli on the final matchday.
Perišić finished his first Inter season by playing 37 matches, including 34 in league, scoring nine goals, which seven of them were in league, as Inter finished fourth in <a href="2015%E2%80%9316%20Serie%20A">Serie A</a>, returning in European competitions after one year absence and was eliminated in the semi-final in the Coppa Italia. He was also Inter's top assist provider with six assists.
2016–17 season.
Perišić opened <a href="2016%E2%80%9317%20Inter%20Milan%20season">his second Inter season</a> by playing in the last 30 minutes of the first matchday as fell away at <a href="A.C.%20ChievoVerona">Chievo</a>. He then scored his first goal of the new season in the "<a href="Derby%20d%27Italia">Derby d'Italia</a>" against Juventus at home, entering in the 69th minute and heading home an Mauro Icardi cross nine minutes later to give Inter second win of the season, also the first in league against Juventus since November 2012.
Perišić played his first European match for Inter on 29 September in team's second <a href="2016%E2%80%9317%20UEFA%20Europa%20League">2016–17 UEFA Europa League</a> <a href="2016%E2%80%9317%20UEFA%20Europa%20League%20group%20stage%23Group%20K">group stage</a> match against <a href="AC%20Sparta%20Prague">Sparta Prague</a>, appearing in the last 27 minutes of a 3–1 away defeat. On 20 November, in the "Derby" against rivals Milan, he first provided the <a href="Antonio%20Candreva">Antonio Candreva</a>'s long-range strike before scoring himself a last minute equalizer, as Inter took one point in the last moments.
On 8 January 2017, Inter's first match of the calendar year, Perišić provided a <a href="Man%20of%20the%20Match">Man of the Match</a> performance by scoring both goals in a 2–1 away win at <a href="Udinese%20Calcio">Udinese</a>; it was his first Inter brace which took his tally up to six goals. This was followed by another splendid individual performance against Chievo six days later as he scored his team's second goal after an individual effort in an eventual 3–1 win.
On 5 February, in the matchday 23 against Juventus at <a href="Juventus%20Stadium">Juventus Stadium</a>, Perišić received his first-ever career <a href="Penalty%20card%23Red%20card">red card</a> as Inter were defeated 1–0. He was subsequently banned for two matches by <a href="Italian%20Football%20Federation">Italian Football Federation</a> (FIGC) for aggressive confrontation of the referee. After Inter appealed the suspension, it was reduced to one match. He returned from suspension on 19 February in the 1–0 win at <a href="Bologna%20F.C.%201909">Bologna</a>, and scored his second brace on 5 March in a 5–1 thrashing of Cagliari at <a href="Stadio%20Sant%27Elia">Stadio Sant'Elia</a>.
On 22 April, Perišić reached double-figures for the first time with Inter after scoring in a 5–4 away defeat against <a href="ACF%20Fiorentina">Fiorentina</a>. On the final matchday, he provided a stunning individual performance by providing two assists after individual efforts, also scoring his 11th goal of the season as Inter thrashed Udinese 5–2 at home end the season on a high. Perišić finished his second Inter season by making 42 appearances in all competitions, including 36 in league, which 31 were as starter, as Inter finished the <a href="2016%E2%80%9317%20Serie%20A">Serie A</a> in seventh position, once again failing to qualify for the <a href="2017%E2%80%9318%20UEFA%20Champions%20League">UEFA Champions League</a>. He scored 11 goals, his highest tally since 2010–11 season with Club Brugge; and also provided ten assists, including eight in Serie A, breaking his last season's record.
2017–18 season.
Perišić started <a href="2017%E2%80%9318%20Inter%20Milan%20season">his third Inter season</a> on a high, first scoring and assisting in the opening day of <a href="2017%E2%80%9318%20Serie%20A">2017–18 Serie A</a> against Fiorentina, then providing two assists in the away match at <a href="A.S.%20Roma">Roma</a> as Inter won 3–1, Inter's first league win at the <a href="Stadio%20Olimpico">Stadio Olimpico</a> in nine years.
On 8 September, Perišić signed a new contract extension with Inter Milan, keeping him at the San Siro until June 2022. Upon signing, Perišić said, "It's a special day, it's certainly emotional and I'm happy after the stress of this summer. Now, we can look forward and I'm only thinking about Inter. After signing, the pitch is the only thing left for me to think about."
His second goal of the season, a late screamer outside the zone against newly promoted <a href="S.P.A.L.%202013">SPAL</a> two days later, was his 20th career Serie A goal. Perišić scored his first <a href="List%20of%20Serie%20A%20hat-tricks">Serie A hat-trick</a> on 3 December in the 5–0 home win over Chievo. His 100th appearance in all competitions for Inter occurred later on 30 December in the goalless draw versus <a href="S.S.%20Lazio">Lazio</a> on matchday 19.
2018–19 season.
Perišić played his first <a href="2018%E2%80%9319%20UEFA%20Champions%20League">Champions League</a> game for Inter on 18 September 2018, in a 2–1 victory over <a href="Tottenham%20Hotspur%20F.C.">Tottenham Hotspur</a>.
In January 2019, English club Arsenal attempted to sign Perišić. He agreed a deal with the club; however, Inter blocked the deal. Teammate <a href="Mauro%20Icardi">Mauro Icardi</a>'s agent <a href="Wanda%20Nara">Wanda Nara</a> spoke out about Perišić's reasons for the departure, speculating that they might be of personal nature. Nara's comments resulted in a fallout between the players, resulting in Icardi being stripped of captaincy and dropped from the team ahead of a <a href="2018%E2%80%9319%20UEFA%20Europa%20League">Europa League</a> away fixture against <a href="SK%20Rapid%20Wien">Rapid Wien</a>.
Perišić featured in 34 matches in <a href="2018%E2%80%9319%20Serie%20A">Serie A</a>, only behind <a href="Samir%20Handanovi%C4%87">Samir Handanović</a> and <a href="Matteo%20Politano">Matteo Politano</a>, scoring 8 goals; hence being the second top scorer for Inter after Icardi. Following the appointment of <a href="Antonio%20Conte">Antonio Conte</a>, Perišić struggled to fit into the new manager's system during <a href="2019%E2%80%9320%20Inter%20Milan%20season%23Pre-season%20and%20friendlies">pre-season</a>.
2019–20 season: Loan to Bayern Munich.
On 13 August 2019, Perišić joined German club <a href="FC%20Bayern%20Munich">Bayern Munich</a> on a season-long loan. Bayern had the option of signing Perišić on a permanent deal in the summer of 2020. On 31 August he scored his first goal for Bayern and provided an assist in a 6–1 victory over <a href="1.%20FSV%20Mainz%2005">Mainz</a>.
On 4 February 2020, during training ahead of a <a href="2019%E2%80%9320%20DFB-Pokal">DFB-Pokal</a> match against <a href="TSG%201899%20Hoffenheim">1899 Hoffenheim</a>, Perišić suffered a right ankle fracture following a tackle from teammate <a href="%C3%81lvaro%20Odriozola">Álvaro Odriozola</a>. He underwent a surgery the same day. He came back to the team on 17 May, coming on for <a href="Serge%20Gnabry">Serge Gnabry</a> in 85th minute of the game against <a href="1.%20FC%20Union%20Berlin">Union Berlin</a>, the club's first game after the <a href="2019%E2%80%9320%20Bundesliga">league</a> suspension due to the <a href="COVID-19%20pandemic%20in%20Germany">COVID-19 pandemic</a>.
On 10 June, he scored the opening goal in a 2–1 victory over <a href="Eintracht%20Frankfurt">Eintracht Frankfurt</a> in the DFB-Pokal semi-final. On 4 July, he provided <a href="Robert%20Lewandowski">Robert Lewandowski</a> with an assist in the <a href="2020%20DFB-Pokal%20Final">DFB-Pokal Final</a> as Bayern defeated <a href="Bayer%2004%20Leverkusen">Bayer Leverkusen</a> 4–2 and secured the domestic <a href="Double%20%28association%20football%29">double</a>.
On 8 August, he scored in a <a href="2019%E2%80%9320%20UEFA%20Champions%20League">Champions League</a> <a href="2019%E2%80%9320%20UEFA%20Champions%20League%20knockout%20phase%23Round%20of%2016">round of 16</a> second leg, as Bayern defeated <a href="Chelsea%20F.C.">Chelsea</a> 4–1 (7–1 <a href="Two-legged%20tie">on aggregate</a>). Six days later, he scored in a <a href="2019%E2%80%9320%20UEFA%20Champions%20League%20knockout%20phase%23Quarter-finals">quarter-final</a> <a href="FC%20Barcelona%202%E2%80%938%20FC%20Bayern%20Munich">8–2 win</a> over <a href="FC%20Barcelona">Barcelona</a> at <a href="Est%C3%A1dio%20da%20Luz">Estádio da Luz</a>. On 23 August, he became the eleventh Croatian to win the Champions League in history, as Bayern defeated <a href="Paris%20Saint-Germain%20F.C.">Paris Saint-Germain</a> 1–0 in the <a href="2020%20UEFA%20Champions%20League%20Final">final</a>.
On 9 September, Bayern announced they had opted not to sign Perišić on permanent deal, after failing to negotiate a deal with Inter and he returned to his parent club.
2020–21 season.
On 31 October 2020, Perišić scored his first goal of the season for Inter Milan in a 2–2 home draw against <a href="Parma%20Calcio%201913">Parma</a>. On 3 November, he scored his first <a href="2020%E2%80%9321%20UEFA%20Champions%20League">Champions League</a> goal for Inter Milan in a 2–3 defeat against <a href="Real%20Madrid%20CF">Real Madrid</a>. During the spring part of the <a href="2020%E2%80%9321%20Inter%20Milan%20season">season</a>, Perišić was praised by Conte for successfully adapting to his system, moving from the position of a <a href="Winger%20%28association%20football%29">winger</a> to that of a <a href="Wing-back%20%28association%20football%29">wing-back</a>.
On 2 May 2021, four matchdays before the end of the season, <a href="U.S.%20Sassuolo%20Calcio">Sassuolo</a> drew 1–1 with <a href="Atalanta%20B.C.">Atalanta</a> at home, meaning that Inter mathematically secured the <a href="2020%E2%80%9321%20Serie%20A">Serie A</a> title. It was Inter's first league title since <a href="2009%E2%80%9310%20Serie%20A">2009–10 season</a>, ending Juventus' nine-season-long league-winning streak. The title was also Perišić's first trophy with the "Nerrazzuri".
2021–22 season.
On 24 November 2021, Perišić was praised for his performance in the 2–0 victory over <a href="FC%20Shakhtar%20Donetsk">Shakhtar Donetsk</a> in the <a href="2021%E2%80%9322%20UEFA%20Champions%20League">Champions League</a>, as he assisted <a href="Edin%20D%C5%BEeko">Edin Džeko</a>'s second goal, while his goal and <a href="Lautaro%20Mart%C3%ADnez">Lautaro Martínez</a>'s goal that he also assisted were ruled out. The victory qualified Inter for the <a href="2021%E2%80%9322%20UEFA%20Champions%20League%20knockout%20phase%23Round%20of%2016">Round of 16</a> for the first time since the <a href="2011%E2%80%9312%20UEFA%20Champions%20League%20knockout%20phase%23Round%20of%2016">2011–12 season</a>.
International career.
Perišić has appeared internationally for the Croatia national <a href="Croatia%20national%20under-17%20football%20team">under-17</a>, <a href="Croatia%20national%20under-19%20football%20team">under-19</a> and <a href="Croatia%20national%20under-21%20football%20team">under-21</a> teams. He participated in the <a href="2011%20UEFA%20European%20Under-21%20Championship%20qualification%20Group%207">2011 UEFA European Under-21 Championship qualification</a> for Croatia, where he scored two goals.
On 26 March 2011, at age 22, Perišić made his debut for the <a href="Croatia%20national%20football%20team">senior national team</a> against <a href="Georgia%20national%20football%20team">Georgia</a>. He was a member of Croatia's squad for <a href="UEFA%20Euro%202012">UEFA Euro 2012</a>, starting in the team's opening two matches against the <a href="Republic%20of%20Ireland%20national%20football%20team">Republic of Ireland</a> and <a href="Italy%20national%20football%20team">Italy</a>, and appearing as a substitute in the team's final match, a 1–0 loss to <a href="Spain%20national%20football%20team">Spain</a>.
During the <a href="2014%20FIFA%20World%20Cup%20qualification%20%E2%80%93%20UEFA%20Group%20A">2014 World Cup qualification</a>, Perišić appeared in 12 matches for Croatia and scored his first international goal in a 1–1 draw with <a href="Belgium%20national%20football%20team">Belgium</a>. On 14 May, Perišić was named in Croatia's 30-man preliminary squad for the <a href="2014%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">2014 World Cup</a>. On 31 May, he scored a brace in a 2–1 win against <a href="Mali%20national%20football%20team">Mali</a> in a World Cup warm-up match in <a href="Osijek">Osijek</a>. Perišić was confirmed as a member of Croatia's final 23-man World Cup <a href="2014%20FIFA%20World%20Cup%20squads%23Croatia">squad</a> on 2 June. Perišić was in Croatia's starting team for the opening match of the 2014 World Cup, a controversial 3–1 defeat to tournament hosts <a href="Brazil%20national%20football%20team">Brazil</a> at the <a href="Arena%20Corinthians">Arena Corinthians</a>, <a href="S%C3%A3o%20Paulo">São Paulo</a>. In the following match, he scored Croatia's second goal as they defeated <a href="Cameroon%20national%20football%20team">Cameroon</a> 4–0. On 23 June, he scored a consolation goal in the team's final <a href="2014%20FIFA%20World%20Cup%20Group%20A">group</a> match, 3–1 defeat to <a href="Mexico%20national%20football%20team">Mexico</a> which eliminated them from the tournament. Despite Croatia's early elimination, Perišić was ranked as the second-best performing player of the group stage by <a href="FIFA">FIFA</a>.
Perišić was Croatia's top goalscorer in <a href="UEFA%20Euro%202016%20qualifying">Euro 2016 qualifying</a>, scoring six goals in nine matches as Croatia qualified in second place in <a href="UEFA%20Euro%202016%20qualifying%20Group%20H">Group H</a>. In Croatia's second <a href="UEFA%20Euro%202016">Euro 2016</a> <a href="UEFA%20Euro%202016%20Group%20D">group</a> match, Perišić scored the opening goal of a 2–2 draw with the <a href="Czech%20Republic%20national%20football%20team">Czech Republic</a>. Five days later, he scored the winning goal against Spain, which secured qualification to the <a href="UEFA%20Euro%202016%20knockout%20phase">knockout stage</a> as group winners for Croatia.
Perišić appeared regularly in Croatia's successful <a href="2018%20FIFA%20World%20Cup%20qualification%20%28UEFA%29">2018 FIFA World Cup qualifying</a> campaign, as they finished runner-up in <a href="2018%20FIFA%20World%20Cup%20qualification%20%E2%80%93%20UEFA%20Group%20I">Group I</a> which sent them to <a href="2018%20FIFA%20World%20Cup%20qualification%20%E2%80%93%20UEFA%20Second%20Round">second round</a>. The team played <a href="Greece%20national%20football%20team">Greece</a>, winning the first leg 4–1, with Perišić scoring the third goal in 33rd minute. Croatia booked their spot to the <a href="2018%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">World Cup</a> final stages in Russia on 12 November by playing a goalless draw in the returning leg. In May 2018, Perišić was named in Croatia's final <a href="2018%20FIFA%20World%20Cup%20squads%23Croatia">squad</a> for the 2018 World Cup. In the third group stage match, Perišić scored in the last minute of the regular time in the 2–1 win over <a href="Iceland%20national%20football%20team">Iceland</a> as Croatia topped <a href="2018%20FIFA%20World%20Cup%20Group%20D">Group D</a> on full points. During Croatia's semi-final match against <a href="England%20national%20football%20team">England</a> on 11 July, Perišić scored Croatia's equaliser in the second half of regulation time, and later also set-up <a href="Mario%20Mand%C5%BEuki%C4%87">Mario Mandžukić</a>'s match-winning goal in the second half of <a href="Overtime%20%28sports%29%23Association%20football%29">extra-time</a> to give Croatia a 2–1 victory, sending the team to the <a href="2018%20FIFA%20World%20Cup%20Final">World Cup final</a> for the first time in their history. He was named <a href="Player%20of%20the%20match">Man of the Match</a>. In the final against <a href="France%20national%20football%20team">France</a> on 15 July, he scored Croatia's temporary equaliser in the first half, although the match eventually ended in a 4–2 defeat to France. Perišić covered the most ground of any player in the tournament, running a total of 72.5 kilometres.
During <a href="UEFA%20Euro%202020%20qualifying">Euro 2020 qualifying</a>, Perišić scored three times–against <a href="Wales%20national%20football%20team">Wales</a> at home and <a href="Slovakia%20national%20football%20team">Slovakia</a> home and away–as Croatia topped <a href="UEFA%20Euro%202020%20qualifying%20Group%20E">Group E</a>. On 19 November 2019, he <a href="Captain%20%28association%20football%29">captained</a> the national team for the first time ever in a friendly 2–1 victory over Georgia, scoring the winning goal. On 8 September 2020, he captained Croatia once again in a 4–2 <a href="2020%E2%80%9321%20UEFA%20Nations%20League%20A%23Group%203">Nations League</a> defeat to France at <a href="Stade%20de%20France">Stade de France</a>.
On 1 June 2021, Perišić made this <a href="List%20of%20men%27s%20footballers%20with%20100%20or%20more%20international%20caps">100th appearance</a> for the national team in a friendly 1–1 draw with <a href="Armenia%20national%20football%20team">Armenia</a> in which he scored Croatia's goal. He was selected in Croatia's <a href="UEFA%20Euro%202020%20squads%23Croatia">final squad</a> for <a href="UEFA%20Euro%202020">UEFA Euro 2020</a>, where he was the team's most efficient performer, scoring twice (in the 1–1 draw with the Czech Republic and the 3–1 victory over <a href="Scotland%20national%20football%20team">Scotland</a>) and assisting once (in the latter match). However, on 27 June, he tested positive for <a href="COVID-19">COVID-19</a> which ruled him out of the squad for the <a href="UEFA%20Euro%202020%20knockout%20phase">knockout phase</a>.
Beach volleyball.
Perišić took part at the <a href="2017%20FIVB%20Beach%20Volleyball%20World%20Tour">2017 FIVB Beach Volleyball World Tour</a> for the Poreč Major tournament, a professional competition, partnering Nikša Dellorco. The pair lost their first match against <a href="%C3%81lvaro%20Morais%20Filho">Álvaro Morais Filho</a> and Saymon Barbosa.
Personal life.
Despite being born in <a href="Split%2C%20Croatia">Split</a>, Perišić grew up in the town of <a href="Omi%C5%A1">Omiš</a>. As a child, he worked on his father's poultry farm.
Perišić married Josipa in 2012, having first met her while they were in high school. The pair have two children: a son, Leonardo, born on 9 October 2012; and a daughter, Manuela, born on 28 July 2014.
